row.c_title: How Writing to Deadlines Can Hold Your Life Together
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on the surprising benefits of having to write a Lingua Franca post every week for seven years.

row.c_title: How Google’s Autotype Contradicts Orwell’s Advice
row.h_desc: To Geoff Pullum’s amusement, Gmail now offers phrases that are exactly the opposite of what the author of Nineteen Eighty-Four said writers should use.

row.c_title: The Web Page That Cannot Exist
row.h_desc: A tiny error on a conference web page provides Geoff Pullum with a concrete example for teaching abstract concepts in philosophy.

row.c_title: A Pocket Brexicon for American Academics
row.h_desc: Academics visiting Britain from the United States this holiday season will have trouble understanding some new words in the newspapers. Geoff Pullum has prepared a helpful Brexit glossary.

row.c_title: Blasphemy and the Strange World of Linguistic Crimes
row.h_desc: The medieval crime of saying things that outrage the pious exists in the 21st century, says Geoff Pullum, making a “safe space” for religion written into the law in some lands.

row.c_title: A Moment of Sympathy for the Old Fogeys and Snoots
row.h_desc: In the matter of “can not” vs. “cannot,” Geoff Pullum detects a flicker of fellow-feeling for the judgmental prescriptive usage pontificators of the world.

Geoff Pullum was asked to write a book about his field for a lay audience and publisher. Two favorable referee reports left him feeling alone and deprived of counsel, so he resorted to the judgment of that harshest but most biased of referees, the one inside his head.

row.c_title: Sir Harold Evans Sneers at a Book He Has Not Read
row.h_desc: Why would a man modify a book on good writing by adding a misguided slur and a misattributed quotation? Geoff Pullum wonders, resentfully.

row.c_title: Pure Gold, Buried Long Ago in the Book Review Columns
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum recalls a prescient observation about the relations between language and psychology, lost seven decades ago in a place so obscure you would never have found it.

row.c_title: What’s in a Name? A Government Loses a National Referendum Over an Adjective
row.h_desc: A referendum to add “North” to a country’s name failed after its president called the renaming “historical suicide.” Geoff Pullum explains why that’s ridiculous.

row.c_title: What’s the Fastest-Growing Language in the U.S.? You’ll Never Guess
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on its rapid spread, the significance of its language family to linguists, and some important speakers.

row.c_title: Nonsense About Universal Translation, Strictly for the Gullible
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is optimistic about linguistics’ application for practical matters. So why do news outlets perpetuate crazy talk about translating animal language?

row.c_title: How the Cold, Dead Hand of John Dryden Still Perpetuates Grammar Myths
row.h_desc: The fiction about not ending sentences with a preposition can be traced back to the whims of one influential 17th-century writer, says Geoff Pullum. And that’s not all.
Is it “a number of X are” or “a number of X is”? It depends. Geoff Pullum discovers that Merriam-Webster’s Concise Dictionary of English Usage will not help you decide.

row.c_title: The Perennial Difficulty of Defining What ‘Descriptive’ Means in Grammar
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is locked in an intractable dispute with a colleague about whether so-called descriptive work on English grammar is in fact prescriptivism in sheep’s clothing.

row.c_title: Chinese Among High-School Seniors (and in the Movies)
row.h_desc: Mandarin is overtaking German among college-bound high-school seniors. Geoff Pullum reflects on what that might mean, and what the job prospects are.

row.c_title: Learning Useless English Grammar in Japan
row.h_desc: A teacher of English sends Geoff Pullum some puzzling exam questions on an arcane corner of grammar. Japanese students are not just drilled on such sentences, he finds, but examined on them in crucial university admission tests.

row.c_title: Avoiding ‘False Titles’: How Some News Publications Try Not to Sound Like News Publications
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum enlists Lane Greene of The Economist to explain why the magazine insists on using explanatory phrases, as in “Uber, a ride-hailing company,” instead.

row.c_title: The Grammar of the Adjective Is Not What’s Wrong With ‘Illegal Alien’
row.h_desc: The Justice Department’s order that undocumented people should be called illegal aliens smacks of Newspeak but is linguistically unobjectionable. What’s nasty is the attitude behind it.

row.c_title: What’s an Anti-Semite? It Depends on Which Politician You Ask
row.h_desc: Can lexicography help solve political disputes about who is or isn’t anti-Semitic? Geoff Pullum doesn’t think so.

row.c_title: Writing on Philosophy: It’s Not Rocket Science. It’s More Complicated Than That.
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles a perfectly formed yet extraordinarily complex and demanding sentence from a recent text. Can he wrestle it into simpler form?

row.c_title: Friendly Communication Across Supposed Language Barriers
row.h_desc: A conversation in a neighborhood shop reminds Geoff Pullum that despite the hostility between India and Pakistan, spoken Hindi and Urdu are almost identical.

row.c_title: The Triumph and Tragedy of Oscar Wilde
row.h_desc: A London performance of An Ideal Husband prompts Geoff Pullum to reflect on all that has changed, 120 years too late for the playwright, since its debut.

row.c_title: Koko Is Dead, but the Myth of Her Linguistic Skills Lives On
row.h_desc: Despite people’s wishful thinking, the famous gorilla did not master sign language, writes Geoff Pullum, but was producing random signs, notably in situation-bound efforts to get food from her trainer.

row.c_title: Strunk at 100: A Centennial Not to Celebrate
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum argues that professors should stop sending students to a thoroughly outdated writing guide — and cites some alternatives.

row.c_title: Another Conquest by the Language That Is Eating the World
row.h_desc: In the Netherlands, colleges are expanding their enrollments by offering courses in English, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: Infinitives Can Be Split: Grammar Conservatives Face the Shock
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum examines the reaction in the letters column to a recent surprising announcement by The Economist. Could Lingua Franca have helped strengthen the magazine’s resolve?

row.c_title: Amazon’s Alexa: Not Yet as Smart as a 5-Year-Old Child
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says natural-language processing is not ready for prime time, much less Amazon Prime.

row.c_title: The Israel/Palestine Dispute Is Ill-Served by Uninformed Grammar Nitpicking
row.h_desc: Ethno-geopolitical affairs in the Middle East are complex, says Geoff Pullum. We do neither side any favors by discussing the tragic maelstrom of hostilities through ignorant quibbles about language.

row.c_title: Hello, Google Duplex? No Artificially Intelligent Calls, Please
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum, examining a new development in artificial intelligence, decides that he’s inclined to continue making his own phone calls.

row.c_title: Fish, Cheese, and Gossip: 2,000 Years of Snobbery in the Suffix ‘-Monger’
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum detects more than a hint of millennia-old bias in words like warmonger.

row.c_title: Watergate, Weinergate, and Windrush: the Naming of Political Scandals
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tracks some of the word-formation processes involved in the coining of names for new media firestorms.

row.c_title: Emoji Are Ruining Grasp of English, Says Dumbest Language Story of the Week
row.h_desc: Poppycock, says Geoff Pullum. Dropping the occasional pictograph into their prose is not going to strip people of the capacity to form sentences.

row.c_title: Can You Explain What a Shibboleth Is?
row.h_desc: Hearing BBC Radio use the word incorrectly, Geoff Pullum examines its Hebrew etymology and ancient history.

row.c_title: Copy Editing and Proofreading a Book: It Takes a Village
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles the editing and proofing of a short book on why linguistics matters, and is glad he wasn’t trying to do it alone.

row.c_title: The Problem with the Ban on ‘There Are’ Constructions
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum wonders why usage advisers are so determined to get us to stop writing “there is” and “there are.” Some existentials (as clauses with those expressions are called) can’t be gracefully rephrased.
Geoff Pullum analyzes the subtle semantic underpinning of Cynthia Nixon’s amusing “unqualified lesbian” quip.

row.c_title: The Adverb That Killed a Friendship
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum watched as a monosyllabic, unstressed adverb terminated a neighborly relationship.

row.c_title: Taleb on Pinker: Neologism and Bile
row.h_desc: Having browsed the latest books by each of these two noted public intellectuals, Geoff Pullum reaches a decision.
Geoff Pullum argues that spam invitations to junk journals and concocted conferences are not just annoying; they do actual harm.

row.c_title: No Overtime Pay for Milk-Truck Drivers (or Professors)
Talking Killer Whales? Gullible Science Journalists More Likely
‘A Foreign Way Which Never Really Caught On’
The Boy from the Isle of Man
The Fine Line Between Errors and Dialect Differences
The Unmentionable Topic of Edinburgh Weather
Answering a Question with a Question
The Right to Tell People What They Do Not Want to Hear
The Ballad of Bentley and Craig
The Strange Language of Harvey Weinstein’s Denial
On the Ropes at Radio London
The Subtle Art of English Ethnic Slurs
Didn’t Know I Would Really Go
Robots Gossiping in a Secret Language?
Worst Sentence Ever Seen in Academic Prose
Why Won’t They Heed Plain Facts?
Dracula, Strunk, and Correct English Usage
Being a Declarative (or Interrogative, or Imperative, or Exclamative)
The Importance of Being a Prince
The Risky Business of Deadpan Humor
The Many First Rules of Politics
The Team Sat in Its Hotel Drinking Its Beers

row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum bemoans the cruel fate that has dragged him away from linguistics and into realms like file conversion software.

row.c_title: Data Mining for Personally Targeted Politics
Once More Into the Fray, Pluto (and Ixion, Among Others)
For Want of a Copy Editor the Sense Was Lost
When Two Negatives Don’t Make a Positive
Agency Style, For Your Eyes Only
If Only I Could Tell You
For Want of an Oxford Comma
The Unoriginality of Orwell’s Critique of Language
An Ill Wind That No One Blows Good
Orgies, Convoys, and Precision in Word Meanings
The Internet Isn’t Changing English. Nor the Converse
The World’s Best Philosopher of Linguistics
Linguification: That’s the Name of the Game
Liars and Snakes: Plumbing New Rhetorical Depths
Syntactic Self-Harm on St James’s Street
Famous Women, Banknotes, and Online Abuse
The Social Consequences of Switching to English
Sentences I Hope Never to Use
Leaps in the Dark: the Discourse of Brexit
To Co-Author, or Not to Co-Author?
The Footprints of a Gigantic Hound
English and Its Undeserved Good Luck
Prepositions as Conjunctions, Whales as Fish
The Third Flaw in the Second Amendment
Sex and Verbs and Rock ’n’ Roll
Pointless Vocabulary Diversity and Grammatical Structure
Best Linguistic Jokes of the 2015 Fringe
The Fringe Is Coming to Town
Lain, the Whom of the Verb World
Having a Problem With ‘Having a Problem With’
Free Speech, the Rough and the Smooth
Renée Zellweger as a Verb? I Don’t Think So
Writing Instructors: Your Pain Is Felt
Talking About Word Aversion on TV
Dumb Writing Advice, Part 2: Yielding to Nitwits
Dumb Writing Advice, Part 1: Word Prohibitions
The Case of the Sinister Buttocks
Grammatical Icing on the Political Cake
Speaking Out Against Hate Speech (Or Not)
The True Secret of Office Packing
The Vague Main Clause of the Second Amendment
And the Other Is a Jellyfish
Brevity and Attractiveness: Misreporting Linguistic Science
Moths to the Flame of Meaning
Linguistic Fuel for a Political Brushfire
The Higgs: Names Becoming Common Nouns
Is the Cognitive Revolution Here Yet?
Can Goofy Headlines Cost You Money?
Who’d Want to Be a Dick Swiveller?
Counting the Languages of the World
Is Strunk Bunk? a Game-Changing New Development
Extractor Fans, Big Brother, and the Passive
You’re Wrong and I’m Changing the Subject
Getting In and Out (and Looked At)

row.h_desc: Voice interaction with machines has been brought up to a useful level not so much by accurate identification of speech, says Geoff Pullum, but by structuring the space of possible conversations.

row.c_title: Keyword Search, Plus a Little Magic
row.h_desc: Looking for keywords in files was dumb until the discovery of a magic additive that made it usable, Geoff Pullum explains.

row.c_title: Why Are We Still Waiting for Natural Language Processing?
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says computer systems should be able to understand simple English questions--and answer them.
Yes, a new word (“slash”) has joined the category of “conjunctions”; but, Geoff Pullum argues, that category should be renamed.

row.c_title: We Do Not Seek to Rule
Orwell and the Not Unblack Dog
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum explains one of his reasons for seeing George Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language” as not just silly but intellectually dishonest.
Why, asks Geoff Pullum, does anybody take seriously George Orwell’s famous recommendation to avoid the phrases that figure most frequently in current writing?
Even under an extraordinarily plaintiff-friendly legal system, says Geoff Pullum, surely a librarian should not have been deemed vulnerable to a libel suit for comments on book quality?
A local government council that proposed dropping apostrophes from street-name signs faced fury from the guardians of punctuation. The guardians are mistaken, says Geoff Pullum.
The maligned adverb “quite” seems to have two opposite meanings, some people say. Not true, Geoff Pullum explains.

row.c_title: Spurious Correlations Everywhere: The Tragedy of Big Data
A Rule Which Will Live in Infamy
One Rule to Ring Them All
Don’t Blame Your Moods on Your Language
What Words to Say, What Sort of Person to Be
Passive Writing at the Daily Planet
Even That Would Be a Grammar
You Are Software; Don’t Greet Me
The Riddle of Frisney and Frarney
When Your Computer Is as Easy to Use as Your Phone
The Case of the Extra Word
Not Rage So Much, but a Modicum of Fear
The Rise and Fall of a Venomous Dispute
Foreign Language Education, Part 3: Accentuating the Positive
More on How to Argue for Foreign-Language Instruction
How to Argue for Foreign Language Instruction
Literary Judgment Marred by Dumb Grammar Myth
More Linguistic Slush From the Arctic
I Will Never Be a Ranter
Attack the Muffled Mendacities of the Administrative Creatures
Mistakes Are Made (But Using the Passive Isn’t One of Them)
In the Time of Declarative Sentences
